misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even integers)
misconceptions.description: The student’s program computes the average acceleration from three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing only the even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for v0, v1, and t, then output the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, accumulate a running sum of the even numbers, and finally print that sum.
symptoms: No loop to process five inputs
No modulo (%) or conditional check for even numbers
Computation is (v1 - v0) / t instead of a sum
Output text refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a solution to a different textbook-style problem (average acceleration) rather than the specified task of summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate the requirements in your own words. Then design the algorithm: read 5 integers in a loop, check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, add even numbers to a sum variable, and finally print the sum with the required message.
related_concepts: Designing algorithms with loops and conditionals
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (variable names, prompt string, formula, and output message) matches an average acceleration problem and not the required sum-of-even-numbers task.

evidence.note: This code solves an average-acceleration physics problem instead of summing five even integers as specified.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves an entirely different problem (calculating average acceleration from physics) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates either complete misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or accidental submission of code from a different assignment.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q1 specifically requires reading exactly 5 integers, filtering for even numbers only using (n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum. The sample run clearly shows: Input '3 8 2 7 4' → Output 'Sum of even numbers: 14'.

Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
No loop structure for processing multiple inputs
No conditional check for even/odd numbers

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Create a loop that runs 5 times, read an integer each iteration, check if (num % 2 == 0) to identify even numbers, accumulate their sum, and print the result.

misconceptions.name: Implements an entirely different problem instead of required sum-of-evens task
misconceptions.description: The submitted program solves a physics-style average acceleration problem (reading v0, v1, t and computing (v1 - v0) / t) instead of the required task of reading 5 integers, selecting the even ones, summing them, and printing the sum. As a result, none of the problem requirements (5 integers, loop, even-number check, accumulator for sum) are implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that submitting a correct Java program that reads some numeric input and computes a formula (in this case average acceleration) is acceptable for this question, possibly because they confused this question with a different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the specified algorithm: read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., via a loop or repeated reads), check each input to see if it is even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, maintain a running sum of only the even numbers, and finally print the sum with the required labeling (e.g., "Sum of even numbers: 14"). A solution to a different problem, even if syntactically correct, does not satisfy the task.
symptoms: Program prompt is "Enter v0, v1, and t:" instead of something like "Enter 5 integers:"
Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers
No loop is used to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers (e.g., n % 2 == 0) appears in the code
Final output label is "The average acceleration is" and prints (v1 - v0) / t rather than a sum of even integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student reused or pasted a solution for a different textbook problem (average acceleration) and did not adapt it to this question, indicating confusion about aligning code with the exact problem specification rather than a misunderstanding of Java syntax or Scanner usage.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm step by step for THIS task: (1) read 5 integers, (2) for each integer, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) if it is even, add it to a running sum, and (4) after processing all 5 values, print the final sum. Compare your program's prompts and output format to the sample run to ensure they match the specification.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code matches a well-known average-acceleration example and shares no structural elements with a sum-of-evens solution (no loop, no modulus operator, wrong prompt, wrong output), making it very likely the student implemented the wrong problem rather than merely omitting a minor detail.

evidence.note: This snippet shows the program is reading three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computing average acceleration, with prompts and output text that do not match the required task of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number detection logic
misconceptions.description: Student has not implemented any conditional logic to detect even numbers. The modulo operator (%) is not used at all to check if a number is even.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the program should process the input values through arithmetic operations (like calculating acceleration) rather than applying conditional logic to filter numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if a number is even, use the modulo operator: if (number % 2 == 0). The modulo operator returns the remainder; if the remainder is 0, the number is even. Only even numbers should be included in the sum.
symptoms: No if statement with modulo operator
No even/odd filtering logic present
Code calculates acceleration instead of filtering for even numbers
No conditional branch based on number parity
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either did not read the problem requirements carefully, or submitted code from a completely different problem without modification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside your loop (when reading each integer), add a conditional: if (number % 2 == 0) { sum += number; }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with no trace of the required even-number check; this is definitively missing.

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
